reviewText: I received this set for Christmas, and I am going to sell it and get the ultimate editions that have been released. One, because I love Harry Potter and this set doesn't do justice to it, and second I am a collector, and an avid blu ray/dvd fan so It upsets me to see what is missing from this set. First, the case is fine, it holds the movies nicely and the blu rays look great, but once you get past the fifth disc you realise that you are just getting a poorly compiled set. For one the later movies are the disc ones of two disc sets, they didn't even try to print a new labels for this set, so each time you see this disc you realise you are only getting half of what is out there. There really are no extas with the last movies, because it's all included on the two disc sets. At least with the first five you get pretty decent extras, but there is so much out there that it seems a waste just to include the movie only version of the last movies.  For casual fans I would recommend it, but if you are like me and love the bonus features, there are better versions out there. I purchased the first movie in the ultimate edition form and am very pleased, the packaging/bonuses are great, and you get so many extras you will be overwhelmed (but in a good way) compared to these editions. I don't like this set because it seemed like they threw it together in order to make a few bucks for the end of the year, they didn't even think about the customers with this one. There were no bonus discs as with other box sets, to put all the extras in one place (to make up for the later movies having so little) But as far as the quality of the movie and how it looks/sounds on blu ray i'd give it 5 stars. and the movies themselves are great (as you know already if you are even reading this) However I think this was just a quick cash grab, but it's cheap enough for the casual fans. and it does free up some room in your collection (doesn't take up that much room compared with the other versions). So like I said for die-hards I'd say look elsewhere, for casual fans, this will probably be enough for you. And this comment has nothing to do with this set per se, but I feel the last two movies (Book 7) should have been combined into one longer movie rather than two seperate ones.  They say it was needed to cover the material, but even with two movies they still overlooked so much material that their point is rendedred moot. If kids are going to wait outside stores until after midnight to buy a book and then read it in one night, then they'd definitely sit through a three hour plus movie. It's all about the money though. I just think it detracts from an overall great franchise. But you can't go wrong with the movies, or the books...especially with the books. I'd recommend reading them first before seeing the movies, and just don't let the omissions bother you too much. The performances are great and the special effects are awesome. So enjoy.

reviewText: In this set, viewers will get all 8 Harry Potter films, in Blu-Ray and full HD quality.  If you enjoy the Harry Potter movies, and don't want tons of special features, this is the set for you.The blu-ray discs do have some basic special features but, do not have the huge amount that the special edition collector sets might have.This set is a great buy.  Every movie for a minimal price.Now, in terms of quality, there are some issues with the set.  It isn't that all of the movies aren't in 1080p, however, the earlier movies were filmed at a time when HD and digital technology was in a newer stage.  So, the earlier movies, while they are scanned or transferred at 1080p, lack the polished, smooth and crisp look that the newer, more modern films have.  It isn't a problem per say, just a reality that a purchaser must be aware of.The audio is great and the newer of the movies are absolutely stunning in HD quality.  The older movies do have some benefit from the transfer but, also some drawbacks as the older CG technologies do not appear to blend or composite quite as well, though only really noticeable to people who look for that kind of thing.The stories are, as they always were, well told interpretations of the book series.  One must always keep in mind that every movie based on a book is just that, an interpretation.  One cannot expect a perfect transition.  Although, in my humble opinion, Dolores Umbridge is just as awful, even with the more limited violence and cruelties compared to the books.If you and your family are fans of the Potter series, this is a great way to get all of them in the best condition and quality possible at a great price.  Don't miss the opportunity.

reviewText: "Harry Potter: The Complete 8 Film Collection"Over the Spring break my family indulged in a Harry Potter film festival, watching all eight movies in the course of a few days. It was great. I was an adult reader of the first book, and made my way through the whole series, even with the tedium at the end. My wife and I saw the first couple of movies together when they came out, but then gave up after that - the first film didn't have the same magic as the book, and the second was just a little too cutesy and coy for my tastes. Maybe we were just too old for this stuff.Anyway, fast forward a decade or so and here we are with a kid whose life is saturated with Potter, Spidey and Star Wars and we figured it was time to just go for it... so break out the popcorn and hand me the remote!It was a great viewing experience, and frankly, more fun than the books, especially the later volumes in the series. At some point the literary enterprise and the Hollywood phenomenon became closely entwined and Ms. Rowling clearly began writing her books almost as if they were production notes for the films. And, as it turns out, that was just fine. "The Deathly Hallows" is a terrible book -- uneventful, dreary, repetitive and full of lifeless exposition -- but the screen version, especially taken in the context of the other films, is quite good. Indeed, watching all the movies together in a short time period was a potent experience, making the characters and their losses and growth more resonant and powerful -- the transitions from childhood to maturity, and the purposeful changes in emotional tone from film to film are more easily seen as part of a purposeful and elegant mosaic. Although Rowling (arguably) may have dropped the ball on the books, her overall vision for the saga comes through well in these films and although Harry remains a relatively flat character, the tragedy and complexity of Severus Snape is impressive in such a mega-mainstream entertainment juggernaut. Chris Columbus's formulaic direction of the first two films threw me off the scent many years ago, but I'm glad I came back to it now. It's a worthwhile journey. (DJ Joe Sixpack, ReadThatAgain childrens media reviews)

Both of the Deathly Hollows movies had a separate "special features" disc.  I have upgraded my evaluation of this set to four stars, from three stars, as finding the subtitle "switch" made a big improvement in my enjoyment and satisfaction with this movie set.

reviewText: I like how a lot of fans are slamming Warner Brothers for offering up a box set containing all eight films in one compact package. They accuse how WB constantly does this for the Harry Potter franchise, and to be fair, WB has been doing incomplete Potter boxed releases for years, starting with "Prisoner of Azkaban" onwards. But when the WB actually makes a nice package with all eight films included, they still complain because there's hardly any bonus material. WB did this for their first four Batman movies before the glorious Batman Anthology came to be, so those fans have been waiting a long time that as well.The set will just have a repressing of the initial releases, and the first three movies include their respective trailers, while "Deathly Hallows Parts 1 & 2" have deleted/extended scenes, so the "no extras" claim doesn't hold as much water. They have some, as opposed to none. Not to mention the quality of the past three Ultimate Editions' bonus features have declined to the point where I just stopped buying them (bulky packaging, no commentary and no extended editions are the deal-breakers). For me, I just want the movies, and this set allows that. For that alone it gets 4 stars. It's a no-frills package but worth it if you just want the movies and save shelf space.If you want a comprehensive box set with tons of extras for each movie, you'll have to wait. Don't buy it if you don't want to.

reviewText: The Harry Potter Collection gives us all 8 films that were produced from 2001 to 2011,giving celluloid life to JK Rowlings impressive written sagas.Impressive sometimes doesn`t even begin to describe the high quality of craftsmanship that went into each and every film.From the direction,to the editing to the plot and so on and so on,everything about these films is top notch all the way.The S/FX just got better and better as the series(and technology)progressed.We saw all the main actors grow up before our very eyes without losing touch of their core characters.To round it out,as if it needs saying,is Rowlings extremely imaginative settings and characters.Her entire take on this world of wizardry and her ability to put her ideas to paper,and it to go onto film,and ALL capture and create literally millions of fans from every part of the globe,is astounding or,as Harry himself would say,brilliant.I won`t go into each film,as the plots are quite well known by now,but I will say I found not one clunker in the group.They are all long films,coming in around 120 minutes or much more,but I never found myself looking at my watch or getting bored:a definite sign someone knew what they were doing.Technically speaking the films are in their original w/s a/r of 1:77:1 and are clear and crisp.All DVD`s come in layered round plastic holders.All seem to sit and fit quite snugly.I had to take one star off this impressive series of films for one reason.Warners decided to re-package the original single disc releases.That is if you have already bought them singly or in the 1-5 or 1-6 sets,you will already have what this one puts out,right down to the disc cover artwork,or lack thereof,and the picture/film hesitations that occur most noticeably in the first five that happen in or around the 75 minute mark of each film.Disappointing.They could have at least made a re-run of the series with new disc artwork and gotten rid of those pesky hesitations.But no,Warners,as is like most companies,had dollar signs in their eyes and rushed this set out to cash in on the Potter craze and keep it alive until their next release,which will be.....who knows when or in what fashion.There are very few extras in any of these discs save for the odd commentary or deleted scenes.But it is these extra scenes which makes me think somewhere down the line Warners will re-issue these films not only with several extra discs for each movies,but also in extended versions,similar to the Lord of the Rings trilogy,which would only enhance them.And the extended versions of the LOTR films are magnificent.Me,I am not that rabid a Potter fan that I want to wait for newer versions down the line,so I decided to get my Potter fix now and straight up,with little or no extras.If you are a big Potter fan,and you are among the countless legions of them,you might want to wait for those inevitable newer and remastered versions down the pike...or get these now and get those later!It is your choice but whatever you decide,you know you will be getting eight wondrous and beautiful films that bring Rowlings wondrous works to beautiful filmic life.Highly recommended.

reviewText: This box set has come in for serious criticism regarding its limits.  Indeed, there can be no doubt that this set doesn't have extended cuts and director's cuts.  However, what it does have is completely satisfying, i.e. high definition versions of the theatrical releases of the films, wonderfully transferred; deleted scenes from each film; documentaries, interviews, commentaries, and the usual fluff that comes with these things; and some video game materials.  Frankly, I do not think they will release the newer versions (extended cuts and director's cuts) as a box sets until they have released all of them individually - they will do it in a way that maximizes sales, based on timing.  That means that these are the only versions we will have for some time as they will prolong the cycle as long as possible.This will sound repetitive, but these are absolutely great films and have been a part of my family experience for the last 11 years.  We watch them together periodically and always made the trek to the cinema to see new releases.  They spurred my children to read their first long books.  Plus, each film is consistently excellent in its own way, quite an accomplishment for a series of 8 films.While we love the films, I doubt that we will want more than these as we are not the kind of fans that Trekkies are.  Thus, for those like us, I warmly recommend this set.  Interestingly, I got the version in British blu-ray for about $50. Given the price of the blu-rays of the final 2 films, that made it worthwhile for us to pay a little more for the entire set - without dvd and other media versions that we would scarcely want anyway.
summary: definitive blu-ray version of theatrical releases, with extras (British version)

reviewText: I was stationed in Yokosuka, Japan when I first watched "Harry Potter And The Sorcerer's Stone" film at a late night showing.  I am also lucky to have watched each of the other seven films at movie theaters.  This 8 film collection includes a short synopsis of each movie and in chronological order.  The eight movies featured (for those who may not have yet got the chance to watch the films): Harry Potter And The Sorcerer's Stone, Harry Potter And The Chamber Of Secrets, Harry Potter And The Prisoner of Azkaban, Harry Potter And The Goblet Of Fire, Harry Potter And The Order Of Phoenix, Harry Potter And The Half Blood Prince, Harry Potter And The Deathly Hallows-Part 1, and Harry Potter And the Deathly Hallows Part 2. The only catch is that one must have a strong desire to get this collection for strictly the movies. The obvious reason being is the inclusion of all of the Harry Potter films to have been released, but extras are not included.  Aside from that caveat, this complete 8 film collection of Harry Potter is best for those who enjoy fantasy films involving friends who unite together to overcome spiritual tests in life

reviewText: I'm not a huge fan of the Harry Potter books. Ms Rowling is a competent, sometimes inspired, story teller, but these books are largely devoid of any "literary" quality that might appeal to adults. This is understandable; one doesn't expect the quality of Evelyn Waugh or Cormac McCarthy from novels aimed at tweens and young adults. *The first two films, directed by Chris Columbus, are too light in tone (both dramatically and photographically), and (even in Harry's confrontation with Tom Riddle and the basilisk) fail to properly foreshadow the darkness that will descend. The criticism that they're "too much like the books" is valid.But starting with "Prisoner of Azkaban", the films are better than the books. They show us what Ms Rowling could not (or chose not to) convey in words -- Harry & friends live an a world that doesn't have a guaranteed happily-ever-after ending. Indeed, the generally "adult" quality of the last six films is a compliment to the producers' good judgement. (Steve Kloves' economical and focused scripts also deserve praise.)The latter films get /so/ dark -- literally -- that a display with good shadow detail is recommended for maximum enjoyment. I don't know how much grain reduction was used (I saw no grain, at any time), but there's plenty of detail, and no visible edge sharpening.* An ex-boss of mine, an ex-English teacher, recommended them as being pretty good. I was disappointed that they were little more than entertaining.
